The fifth annual contest for
Maryland and the District of Columbia of the Intercollegiate Peace
Association, held in McCoy Hall
last Friday night, was won by Leo
A. Codd, of Loyola College, with
Joseph T. Bartlett, Jr., of Hopkins,
second.'
James P. Needham,of Georgetown
University, was the first speaker of
the evening. His oration was on "International Peace," and in it he
painted a graphic picture of the
esent European. war and what it
meant to the peace movement. His
voice was good, his gestures natural
and his speech well arranged.
Luther T. Mile, Jr., of St. John's
College, spoke next on the same
subject. He dealt rather with the
subject of peace as an issue of civilization, why it was to 1))e desired and
how it was to be achieved. His
speech, while ably thought out, was
not as well delivered as that of the
previous speaker.
The next orator was Joseph T.
Bartlett, Jr., who, representing
Hopkins, spoke , on "The Challenge
of the Times." His speech was an
attack against nationalism and militarism, a weighing of the past and a
planning of the future. .Bartlett
more than justified the confidence
placed in him, speaking in a calm,
impressive fashion and presenting
his strong arguments in a way
which held the audience suspended
until his very last utterance.
The final speaker of the evening,
Leo A. Codd, of Loyola College,
however, surpassed all the other
participants in the ease of his delivery and in the effective manner
in which he handled his remarkably
clear voice. He spoke on "Peace
and the Individual," and although
he acquitted himself almost faultlessly as a speaker, his subject matter was not up to the standard set
by the previous speakers.
The announcement of the aard
was made by Rev. C. A. Rubenstein on behalf of his fellow judges,
Messrs. William H. Morris, Henry
D. Mentzel, Edwin T. Dickerson
and Charles H. Knapp.
Mr. Theodore Marburg was the
presiding officer of the evening, and
while awaiting the decision of the
judges himself delivered a brief
summary of the effect which the
present war has had upon the peace
movement. He, as well as Dr.
Rubenstein, called attention to the
fact that the whole movement was
benefited by the holding of these
contests and by the orations of such
men as the contestants of the evening.

Johns Hopkins will have the privilege of hearing three men of note
this week. Dr. John Calvin Ferguson, who for many years held important positions in China, will
speak Monday, March 22, at 5 P.
M. on "Chinese Art," a subject in
regard to which there is no better
authority. Dr. Ferguson was for
nine years president of Nanking
University and for five years president of Nanyang University. He
has been connected with the Chinese
Government for a number of years,
and only resigned office to devote
his time more fully to literary and
art. studies. It will be an opportunity to hear one so eminently qualified to speak on a little known subject, for the art of the Orient is
peculiar to itself and scarcely understood by many.
On Monday night at 8 o'clock
Mr. Harrington Emerson will give
the second lecture of four, which
he is delivering under the auspices
of the Department of Engineering.
Prominent in financial work, he
gained wide recognition as an efficiency engineer on account of his
results on the Santa Fe System.
He has written a number of books
bearing upon his profession, such
as "Efficiency as the Basis for Operation and Wages," and "The
Twelve Principles of Efficiency."
The subject of Mr. Emerson's lecture Monday evening will be "The
Fundamentals of Organization."
Dr. David Talbot Day, of the
United States Bureau of Mines,
who will give illustrated lectures
Tuesday and Wednesday, March
23 and 24, at 5 P. M., in McCoy
Hall, received his A.B. and Ph.D.
degrees from Hopkins in 1881 and
1884. Since that time he has been
connected with the United States
Geological Survey as director of
the mining and mineral resources
divisions, and since 1907, in charge
of the petroleum investigations. Dr.
Day is a geologist of note, and his
lectures promise to be of value to
all those interested in that subject,
or to those desirous of knowing the
mineral resources and wealth of the
United States.

The Board of Managers of the
Musical Clubs began the work of
widening the scope of their activity
last Tuesday, when a large number
of candidates answered President
Baker's call for the organization of
a mandolin club. This club will
start out on its work directly following the Easter examinations, and
will work in conjunction with the
two clubs which formerly made up
the Combined, Musical Clubs.
Although it would seem that this
is a late time for the organization
of another musical activity, the
management has entered into this
new field with a view to increasing the efficiency of the clubs as a
whole for several important concerts and trips which it hopes to
arrange between now and the end
of the year. The need for such a
club has been felt for some time, and
in view of the possibility of several
important engagements in the near
future, an attempt will be made
to put the club well on its feet in
as short a space of time as possible.
The leader of the new club will
be L. L. Jacobs, '13, who is a student at the Medical School. Mr.
Jacobs has for some time enjoyed
the distinction of being one of the
best mandolin players in this part
of the country, and the club is fortunate in having his services as
director. The club will be made
up of mandolins, mandolutes, banjomandolins, banjos, guitars, ukulele
and bass banjo. Rehearsals will be
held twice a week.
After their concert at Catonsville,
in which the Glee and Instrumental
Clubs attained to the usual degree
of success which has. marked their
work this season, the musicians decided to take a rest during the period directly preceding examinations. There will be several concerts after the Easter vacation, and
the management is working steadily
on plans for an extended trip, details of which will be announced as
soon as matters are more firmly in
hand.
The season will this year extend
to the end of the academic term
in June, or possibly later. This
unusual length of schedule is due
partly to the fact that the clubs
were late in starting out this year,
owing to the difficulties of reorganization, and partly to the desire on
the part of the management to get
the organization in as good a condition as possible for the season of

Charles Francis Adams, publicist,
died of pneumonia at 2 o'clock
on Friday morning at his winter
home, 1701 Massachusetts avenue,
Washington, D. C., in his eightieth
year. He had been ill a week with
the grip. His wife, who was Miss
Mary Hone Ogden, of Newport,
R. I., at the time of their marriage
November 8, 1865, was with him.
He left two sons and three daughters. His great-grandfather was
John Adams,.the second President
of the United States, and his grandfather, John Quincy Adams, was
the sixth President. He was the
son, of Charles Francis Adams,
minister to England, and his mother
was Abigail Brown Brooks, of Boston, where he was born May 27,
1835.
The career of Charles Francis
Adams included the activities of
soldier, author, historian, orator and
railway management. Like other
members of his distinguished family, he was a graduate of Harvard
University, in the class of 3856, and
two years later he was admitted to
the Massachusetts bar. He served
through the Civil War, entering
the Union Army as lieutenant in
the First Massachusetts Cavalry,
December 28, 1861, was promoted
to captain after a year's service, and
was successively lieutenant-colonel,
colonel and brevet brigadier-general
of the Fifth Massachusetts Volunteers during the last two years of
the war.
Mr. Adams was known as one of
the foremost historians of the country, his interest chiefly being centered in the history and the political and economic problems of the
United States. A large part of his
writings had to do with the Civil
War. A biography of his father,
including a review of the diplomatic
negotiations between the United
States and Great Britain over Civil
War problems, is considered one of
his notable books.
He gave on several occasions series of lectures at Johns Hopkins,
and was always received with much
enthusiasm.
His civic work included the chairmanship of the committee which
planned the metropolitan park system in Boston and vicinity. He
was an overseer of Harvard University from 1892 to 1907.
Although he never sought public office, Charles Francis Adams
took an active part in political affairs, but always as an independent,
both in his speeches and writings.

TRACK MEN WORK AT HOME WOOD
Despite Cold Weather and Soft Track,
Coach England's Squad Begins Preparation for Hard Outdoor Season.

In spite of the cold weather, the
track squad moved to Homewood
last Monday and began its preparation for the hard outdoor schedule.
During the two weeks previous
there had been no practices, as it
is customary to give the men a short
rest between the indoor and outdoor seasons. Since examinations
are now so near, and the "black
list" is one of the most formidable
opponents of the squad, the attendance at practice will probably remain rather small until after the
holidays.
The track is not yet in condition
so that hard training cannot begin
for the present at least, but steady
workouts are being carried on every
day upon the cinders outside the
athletic field fence. This sort of
work .will continue during the
spring vacation; with a hard dual
meet but a month off, there is no
time to be lost.
This first meet is with Navy on
April 17. Although there are no
events in, this meet in which one
man runs'more than a quarter mile,
there will be a one-mile relay race.
Coach England is trying to arrange
with the Navy managers to have
two teams from each side entered
in this relay this year, and make
the count five and three for first
and second places, respectively, as
in the other events of the meet.
The old way was to have but one
team from each side, and only the
winning team score. Since the
three distance events are ruled out,
with only one relay team, there is
a possibility for only a small number of men to enter the meet. The
point has not yet been decided.

SENIORS TO FEAST MAY 10

After the temporary excitement
incident upon the holding of the
junior and sophomore banquet, the
quiet and calm prevalent at the
present time are somewhat of a disappointing anti-climax. The seniors
will not feast until the evening of
May 10, while the date when the
first-year men will come toe-ether
has not as yet been announced.
There are numerous reasons for
the postponment of the senior banquet. Most of the men in the
graduating class are busily engaged
with work on the various spring
athletic teams, or in the preparation
of the Hullabaloo. And, even if it
were perfectly convenient for them
to come together in the immediate
future, it is generally felt that the
affair will be a more enjoyable one
if it is held later in the season,
when, like the program arranged
for Senior Week, it will help to
make as enjoyable as possible the
last few weeks of the 191$ Class at
the University.
The freshmen,'apparently unconvinced by the course adopted by
the sophomores on the recent occasion of their banquet, have refused
to make public the date of their own
gala occasion. In doing this, they
are following the precedent of former years, after all necessity for
such action has departed. It is generally believed that their banquet
will take place immediately after the
Easter vacation.

The fifth annual contest for

James P. Needham,of Georgetown
University, was the first speaker of
the evening. His oration was on "International Peace," and in it he
painted a graphic picture of the
esent European. war and what it
meant to the peace movement. His
voice was good, his gestures natural
and his speech well arranged.
Luther T. Mile, Jr., of St. John's
College, spoke next on the same
subject. He dealt rather with the
subject of peace as an issue of civilization, why it was to 1))e desired and

The next orator was Joseph T.
Bartlett, Jr., who, representing

of the Times." His speech was an
attack against nationalism and militarism, a weighing of the past and a
planning of the future. .Bartlett
more than justified the confidence
placed in him, speaking in a calm,
impressive fashion and presenting
his strong arguments in a way
which held the audience suspended
until his very last utterance.

Leo A. Codd, of Loyola College,
however, surpassed all the other
participants in the ease of his delivery and in the effective manner
in which he handled his remarkably
clear voice. He spoke on "Peace
and the Individual," and although
he acquitted himself almost faultlessly as a speaker, his subject matter was not up to the standard set

D. Mentzel, Edwin T. Dickerson
and Charles H. Knapp.

summary of the effect which the

movement. He, as well as Dr.
Rubenstein, called attention to the
fact that the whole movement was
benefited by the holding of these
contests and by the orations of such
men as the contestants of the evening.

Coach England's Squad Begins Preparation for Hard Outdoor Season.

In spite of the cold weather, the
track squad moved to Homewood
last Monday and began its preparation for the hard outdoor schedule.
During the two weeks previous
there had been no practices, as it
is customary to give the men a short
rest between the indoor and outdoor seasons. Since examinations
are now so near, and the "black
list" is one of the most formidable
opponents of the squad, the attendance at practice will probably remain rather small until after the
holidays.
The track is not yet in condition
so that hard training cannot begin
for the present at least, but steady
workouts are being carried on every
day upon the cinders outside the
athletic field fence. This sort of
work .will continue during the
spring vacation; with a hard dual
meet but a month off, there is no
time to be lost.
This first meet is with Navy on
April 17. Although there are no
events in, this meet in which one
man runs'more than a quarter mile,
there will be a one-mile relay race.
Coach England is trying to arrange
with the Navy managers to have
two teams from each side entered
in this relay this year, and make
the count five and three for first
and second places, respectively, as
in the other events of the meet.
The old way was to have but one
team from each side, and only the
winning team score. Since the
three distance events are ruled out,
with only one relay team, there is
a possibility for only a small number of men to enter the meet. The
point has not yet been decided.

LULL IN BANQUET SEASON;
SENIORS TO FEAST MAY 10

After the temporary excitement
incident upon the holding of the
junior and sophomore banquet, the
quiet and calm prevalent at the
present time are somewhat of a disappointing anti-climax. The seniors
will not feast until the evening of
May 10, while the date when the
first-year men will come toe-ether
has not as yet been announced.
There are numerous reasons for
the postponment of the senior banquet. Most of the men in the
graduating class are busily engaged
with work on the various spring
athletic teams, or in the preparation
of the Hullabaloo. And, even if it
were perfectly convenient for them
to come together in the immediate
future, it is generally felt that the
affair will be a more enjoyable one
if it is held later in the season,
when, like the program arranged
for Senior Week, it will help to
make as enjoyable as possible the
last few weeks of the 191$ Class at
the University.
The freshmen,'apparently unconvinced by the course adopted by
the sophomores on the recent occasion of their banquet, have refused
to make public the date of their own
gala occasion. In doing this, they
are following the precedent of former years, after all necessity for
such action has departed. It is generally believed that their banquet
will take place immediately after the
Easter vacation.
